title: 111_hr5105
content: The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section establishing the Chief Veterinary Officer position within the Department of Homeland Security. The Department of Homeland Security has a Chief Veterinary Officer appointed by the Secretary, responsible for veterinary public health, emergency preparedness, food defense, and agriculture security. The officer must be a veterinarian with relevant professional experience. The Chief Veterinary Officer in the Department of Homeland Security is responsible for veterinary public health, food defense, and agriculture security. They advise the Secretary on these issues, provide guidance for the health of working animals, and lead policy initiatives on food and agricultural incidents. The Chief Veterinary Officer in the Department of Homeland Security leads policy initiatives on domestic preparedness for agricultural terrorism, serves as the main contact for veterinary preparedness and response research, and shares homeland security veterinary information with relevant departments. Additionally, the Chief Veterinary Officer is tasked with reporting to Congress on the state of the Department's working animals each fiscal year. This report includes details such as the number of animals in service, their components, missions, and the homeland security activities conducted. The Chief Veterinary Officer in the Department of Homeland Security must provide advance notice to Congress before any reorganization that affects their responsibilities.
